choices.text: May be caused by fungi or bacteria

questions.text: Mycetoma, a chronic, specific, granulomatous, destructive disease, involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) May be caused by fungi or bacteria Explanation: Some important point
regarding mycetoma- ? Chronic, specific, granulomatous, progressive, destructive inflammatory
disease, which involves the skin, subcutaneous tissues and underlying deeper structures. ? Causative
organism may be true fungi (eumycetoma) or bacteria (actinomycetoma). Mycetoma belt lies
between the latitudes 15° south and 30° north, comprising the countries of Sudan, Somalia, Senegal,
India, Yemen, Mexico, Venezuela, Columbia, Argentina and a few others. ? Route of infectioninoculation
of the organism that is resident in the soil through a traumatised area. ? Pathognomonic
feature - Triad of painless subcutaneous mass, multiple sinuses and seropurulent discharge. During
the active phase of the disease the sinuses discharge grains, the colour of which can be black,
yellow, white or red depending upon the organism. Pain supervenes when there is secondary
bacterial infection. It may cause tissue destruction, deformity, disability, and death in extreme cases.
? Common sites are those that come in contact with soil (foot 70%, hand 12%, others are knee, arm,
leg, head and neck, thigh and perineum while rare sites are the chest, abdominal wall, facial bones,
mandible, testes, paranasal sinuses and eye). There may be areas of local hyperhidrosis due to
sympathetic overactivity or increased local temperature due to raised arterial blood flow caused by
the chronic inflammation. Regional lymph nodes are small and shotty. Lymphadenopathy is common
due to secondary bacterial infection, lymphatic spread of mycetoma or a local immune response to
the disease. Spread via the blood stream can occur. Therefore surgery in mycetoma under local
anaesthesia is contraindicated. ? Local spread occurs predominantly along tissue planes. Lymphatic
spread, more common in actinomycetoma. ? It is not contagious. Granuloma increases in size, and
the overlying skin becomes stretched, smooth, shiny and attached to the lesion. In eumycetoma, it is
usually gradual and delayed while in actinomycetoma, invasion to deeper tissues occurs earlier and is
more extensive. The tendons and nerves are spared until very late in the disease and trophic
changes are rare because the blood supply is adequate. ? Plain radiograph-Periosteal reaction with
new bone spicules may create a sun-ray appearance and Codman's triangle, not unlike an osteogenic
sarcoma. USG can differentiate between eumycetoma and actinomycetoma as well as between
2
mycetoma and other conditions which is useful for surgery, MRI-The 'dot-in-circle sign, which
indicates the presence of grains, is highly characteristic. Biopsy and FNAC are confirmatory and helps
in distinguishing between eumycetoma and actinomycetoma. Deep surgical biopsy is always needed
for culture. ? Management:- Actinomycetoma - combined drug therapy with amikacin sulphate and
co-trimoxazole in the form of cycles is the treatment of choice. Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid,
rifampacin, sulphonamides, gentamicin and kanamycin are used as a second line of treatment.
Eumycetoma- ketoconazole, intraconazole and voriconazole are the drugs of choice. They may need
to be used for up to a year. Surgery is indicated for small localised lesions, resistance to medical
treatment. The surgical options are wide local and debulking excisions and amputations. The
amputation rate is 10-25%. The recurrence rate 25 to 50%.

The 'gold standard' for the diagnosis of GORD (Gastro-Oesophageal Reflux Disease) is

Which of the following factors predispose to the development of incisional hernia? 
1. Malnutrition
2. Postoperative wound infection 
3. Non-absorbable suture material. 
4. Immunocompromised patient
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 1, 2 and 4 Explanation: Some important points regarding incisional
hernia ? Occurs in 10-50% of laparotomy incisions and 1-5% of laparoscopic port-site incisions due to
disruption of the musculofascial layers of a wound in the early postoperative period. ? Factors
predisposing to development of incisional hernia:- patient factors (obesity, general poor healing due
to malnutrition, immunosuppression or steroid therapy, chronic cough, cancer), wound factors (poor
quality tissues, wound infection) and surgical factors (inappropriate suture material, incorrect suture
placement, poor surgical technique). ? Obstruction is common but strangulation is rare due to wide
neck.

1. Ranson and Glasgow score 
2. APACHE score

Select the correct answer using the code given below.

Which of the following statements regarding a patient of liver trauma are correct? 
1. Liver is the most common organ injured following abdominal trauma. 
2. Surgical exploration (laparotomy) is required in haemodynamically unstable patients and patients with free intraperitoneal fluid on FAST.
3. Contrast enhanced CT abdomen should be done in haemodynamically stable patients. 
4. Blunt injuries have a higher mortality as compared to penetrating injuries. 
Select the correct answer using the code given below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 2, 3 and 4 Explanation: Spleen is the most common intra-abdominal
organ injured in abdominal trauma liver is second most. Blunt trauma is more common and has a
higher mortality than penetrating injuries. Blood loss is the major early complication of liver injuries.
All lower chest and upper abdominal stab wounds, severe crushing injuries often combine rib
fractures, haemothorax and damage to the spleen and/or liver are at risk. Focused assessment
sonography in trauma (FAST) diagnose free intraperitoneal fluid. Patients with free intraperitoneal
fluid on FAST and haemodynamic instability, and patients with a penetrating wound, require a
laparotomy along with ABC resuscitation protocol. Haemodynamically stable patient should have a
contrast-enhanced CT scan. T/t-Coagulopathy correction, suturing of lacerations, resection in major
vascular injury, packing in diffuse parenchymal injury. Complications of liver injury Intrahepatic
haematoma, liver abscess, bile collection, biliary fistula, hepatic artery aneurysm, arteriovenous
fistula, arteriobiliary fistula, liver failure

questions.text: The least marked function of a human spleen is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Reservoir function Explanation: Function of spleen:- ? Immune function.
The spleen contains 66.5% and 10-15% of the body's total T and B lymphocyte. It processes foreign
antigens and is the major site of IgM production. ? Filter function. Removes effete platelets, and red
blood cells. Iron removed from haemoglobin during red cell breakdown and is returned to plasma.
Also removed bacteria particularly pneumococci. ? Pitting. Inclusions from red cells are removed, and
repaired red cells returned to the circulation. Howell-Jolly and Heinz bodies, which represent nuclear
remnants and precipitated haemoglobin or globin subunits, respectively. ? Reservoir function. In
humans it is less marked. Enlarged spleen may contain larger amount of the blood volume. ?
Cytopoiesis. From the fourth month of intrauterine life, some degree of haemopoiesis occurs in the
fetal spleen. May also occur in myeloproliferative disorders, thalassaemias and chronic haemolytic
anaemias.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the causes of retroperitoneal fibrosis? 
1. Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis (CAPD) 
2. Lymphoma 
3. Drugs
4. Carcinoid tumours 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 2, 3 and 4 Explanation: Retroperitoneal fibrosis ? Rare diagnosis,
characterised by the development of a flat grey/white plaque of tissue, which is found first in the low
lumbar region then spreads laterally and upwards to encase the common iliac vessels, ureters and
aorta. Allied to other fibromatoses (others being Dupuytren's contracture and Peyronie's disease). ?
Causes: Benign-Idiopathic (Ormond's disease), chronic inflammation, extravasation of urine,
retroperitoneal irritation by leakage of blood or intestinal content, aortic aneurysm (inflammatory
type), trauma, drugs (chemotherapeutic agents and previously methysergide). Malignant-
Lymphoma, carcinoid tumours, secondary deposits (especially from carcinoma of stomach, colon,
breast and prostate) ? C/F- chronic backache or occur as a result of compromise to involved
structures, e.g. lower limb or scrotal oedema secondary to venous occlusion, or chronic renal failure
secondary to ureteric obstruction. ? T/t-Treatment of cause, immunomodulation with steroids,
tamoxifen and ureteric stenting etc.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Urgent Explanation: Triage deciding who receives priority when faced with hundreds of seriously injured victims

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy has recurrent history of pain and swelling below his left ear, which generally lasts for 3-7 days' and improves mildly after a course of antibiotics. Sialography shows punctuate sialectasis. He should be treated by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Endoscopic washouts and antibiotics Explanation: Recurrent parotitis of
childhood-Characterised by rapid swelling of one or both parotid glands, which is increased by
chewing and eating. Fever and malaise usually last from 3 to 7 days, followed by a quiescent period
of weeks to several months. Unknown aetiology; presents between 3-6 years and variable prognosis.
Sialography is diagnostic shich shows a characteristic punctate sialectasis likened to a 'snowstorm.
T/t is regular endoscopic washouts and long courses of antibiotics. HIV associated sialadenitis-
Presentation of HIV-associated sialadenitis is very similar to classical Sjögren's syndrome in
adulthood. Multiple parotid cysts, cause gross painless parotid swelling and facial disfigurement. CT
and MRI demonstrate the characteristic 'Swiss cheese' appearance of multiple large cystic lesions.
T/t- Aspiration and antiretroviral drug. Parotid duct stone- Sialolithiasis is 20% in parotid gland and
80% in submandibular gland. Parotid duct stones are usually radiolucent; frequently located at the
confluence of the collecting ducts, at the point the duct courses over the masseter muscle or in the
distal aspect of the parotid duct adjacent to the parotid papilla. Investigation -USG. The same
treatment applies to parotid stones as to submandibular duct stones. Small stones (-4 mm) retrieved
by baskets, up to 8 mm can be broken with lithotripsy and > 8 mm diameter removed by endoscopic
assisted surgery and preserving the gland. Parotid duct strictures - Strictures are common in the
parotid gland and are responsible for 20% of obstruction. Strictures respond to dilatation and
endoscopic washouts with steroid solutions. Papillary obstruction- Obstructive parotitis, can be
caused by trauma to the parotid papilla. The partial obstruction over a protracted period leads to
dilation of the duct and an entity called 'mega-duct. Drainage done by progressive dilatation of the
punctum and the insertion of a stent. Papillotomy should not done due to stricture formation.

choices.text: Associated injuries of abdomen or chest

questions.text: Hypotension in an unconscious head injury patient is most commonly due to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Associated injuries of abdomen or chest Explanation: Cushing's
response (hypertension and bradycardia) may be seen in patients with altered consciousness
secondary to raised ICP may be due to head injury. Hypotension alongside hypoxia as a major cause
of secondary brain injury. A single episode of hypotension with a systolic blood pressure of < 90> 65 mmHg in severely head-injured patients. In the injured brain, cerebral
autoregulation may be impaired. Cerebral blood flow is dependent on MAP with a fall in MAP leaving
the brain susceptible to ischaemia, and a rise in MAP resulting in hyperaemia, increased cerebral
blood volume and thus raised ICP.

Which of the following are included in triple assessment in case of breast? 
1. Clinical assessment
2. Radiological assessment 
3. Histopathological assessment 
4. Sentinel lymph node biopsy 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Triple assessment used for diagnosis of
suspected carcinoma of breast. It is combination of clinical assessment (age, examination),
radiological imaging (USG and mammography) and a tissue sample taken for either cytological
(FNAC) or histological (trucut/ corecut biopsy) analysis. Its diagnostic accuracy is 99.9%.

choices.text: The male to female ratio is 9:1.

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct regarding Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumour (GIST)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 50% arise from stomach Explanation: Some important point regarding
Gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs):- Arise in any part of the gastrointestinal tract, 50% in the
stomach. Previously known as leiomyoma and leiomyosarcoma. Mesenchymal origin. M: F=1:1.
Associated with a mutation in the tyrosine kinase c-kit oncogene and sensitive to the tyrosine kinase
antagonist imatinib. Tumours with mutations in exon 11 of c-kit are particularly sensitive to this drug.
Tumor size and mitotic index are the best predictors of metastasis. Peritoneal and liver metastases
are most common but lymph nodes are extremely rare. Because the mucosa overlying the tumour is
normal, endoscopic biopsy can be uninformative unless the tumour has ulcerated. Targeted biopsy by
endoscopic ultrasound is more helpful. Tumours > 5 cm in diameter have metastatic potential. If
easily resectable, surgery is the primary mode of treatment. Small tumours-wedge excision, larger
tumours-a gastrectomy or duodenectomy but lymphadenectomy is not required. The prognosis of
advanced metastatic GISTs has been dramatically improved with imatinib chemotherapy but
resection of metastases, especially from the liver, still has an important role.

The commonest variety of peritoneal metastasis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Discrete nodules Explanation: Secondary tumours of peritoneum
Carcinomatosis peritonci:- This is a terminal event in many cases of Ca stomach, colon, ovary or
other abdominal organs, even breast and bronchus. Both parietal and visceral peritoneum is studded
with secondary growths and the peritoneal cavity. The main forms of peritoneal metastases are: (1)
discrete nodules (most common) variety; (ii) plaques varying in size and colour; and diffuse
adhesions (late stage ), late stage gives rise to a 'frozen pelvis. Gravity determines the distribution of
malignant cells within the peritoneal cavity. Pseudomyxoma peritonei:- Rare condition, common in
women. The abdomen is filled with a yellow jelly, large quantities of which are often encysted. Most
cases arise from a primary appendiceal tumour with secondary implantation on to one or both
ovaries. C/F- Painless abdominal distension and usually no impairment of general health. Does not
give rise to extraperitoneal metastases but causes symptoms and complications are due to tumour
bulk. Diagnosis- USG, CT scanning and laparotomy. T/t-Masses of jelly are scooped out. Appendix and
ovarian tumour should be excised. Definitive treatment by complete cytoreduction' (Sugarbaker
technique) in which the right hemicolon, spleen, gall bladder, and greater and lesser omentum are
excised, along with stripping of the peritoneum from the pelvis, diaphragm, and surface of liver
(uterus and ovaries) + Intraoperative heated chemotherapy (mitomycin C).

questions.text: When the hernia extends between the layers of abdominal wall muscles and not directly through them, it is called

Which of the following are tension-free inguinal hernia repairs? 
1. Stoppa's repair 
2. Lichtenstein's repair 
3. Laparoscopic TEP repair 
4. Desarda's repair 
Select the correct answer using the code given
below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Lichtenstein described a tension-free, simple,
flat, polypropylene mesh repair for inguinal hernia. Stoppa, repair is open totally extraperitoneal
mesh repair. Desarda operation where a 1- to 2-cm strip of external oblique aponeurosis lying over
the inguinal canal is isolated from the main muscle then sutured to the conjoint tendon and inguinal
ligament, reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. As the abdominal muscles contract, this
strip of aponeurosis tightens to add further physiological support to the posterior wall. Open suture
repair technique is not a tension free repair. Hernia system is a two-layered mesh in which inner layer
is placed deep to transversalis fascia and the outer layer superficial to it.

1. Surgical resection has a limited role in curative treatment of lung cancer. 
2. Pattern of disease and prognosis of cat cell carcinoma are different to other varieties in the lungs. 
3. Small cell lung cancer is a type of Neuroendocrine Tumour (NET). 
4. Squamous cancer appears as a cavitating tumour in the lungs. 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.

1. It is lined by stratified squamous epithelium. 
2. It is derived from hair follicle.
3. It is also called sebaceous cyst. 
4. It is not fixed to the skin. 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.

Which of the following are correct about glomus tumour? 
1. It arises from Sucquet-Hoyer canals.
2. Its usual site is nail bed. 
3. It is usually a small purple nodule.
4. It is painless. 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Glomus tumour:- These arise from a
subcutaneous AV shunt (Sucquet-Hoyer canals), in the corium of the nail bed or volar fingertip.
Usually in 5 decade. Small purple nodule measuring a few mm in size, which is painful in response to
insignificant stimuli, including cold exposure; patients sometimes labeled as malingering. Subungual
varieties may be invisible causes of paroxysmal digital pain. Treatment is excision. Repair nail bed if
subungual. MRI may occasionally detect tumour Glomus jugulare (Glomus tumour):- Middle ear
tumours are rare with the most common being a glomus tumour. It arise from nonchromaffin
paraganglionic tissue. Carotid body tumour arising in the neck is an example of this type of tumour.
In the temporal bone, three types of glomus tumour are recognised and classification depends on the
location: glomus tympanicum (arising in the middle ear), glomus jugularae (arising next to the jugular
bulb) and glomus vagale (skull base). Symptoms are pulsatile synchronous tinnitus, conductive and
sensorineural hearing loss, and lower cranial nerve palsies. Palsies of CNS VII, IX, X. XI and/or XII may
occur. The classical sign is a cherry-red mass lying behind the tympanic membrane. TOC is
preoperative embolisation followed by surgical excision. Radiotherapy is also effective.

questions.text:
As per the PC & PNDT Act, permission will be given to perform the tests for detection of which of the following? 
1. Chromosomal abnormalities 
2. Haemoglobinopathies 
3. Sex-linked genetic diseases
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: The preconception and prenatal diagnostic
technique (Prohibition of Sex Selection Act, 1994 amended up to Feb. 2003) It prohibits sex selection
before or after conception. Detection of only following abnormalities permitted: (a) Chromosomal
abnormalities, (b) Genetic metabolic diseases, (c) Hemoglobinopathies, (d) Sex-linked genetic
diseases, (e) Congenital anomalies. (f) Any other abnormalities as may be specified by the central
supervisory board. Following condition in written must be fulfilled (a) Pregnant lady must be > 35
years, (b) Undergone two or more miscarriages or fetal loss, (c) Exposed to potentially teratogenic
agents, e.g. drugs, radiation, infection or chemicals, (d) She or her spouse has a family history of
mental retardation or physical deformities such as spasticity or any other genetic disease, (e) Any
other conditions as may be specified by the central supervisory board. Written consent of woman is
obtained and communicating the sex of fetus must be prohibited.

questions.text:
Regarding the phenomenon of 'lightening'in primigravida at term pregnancy, which one of the
following statements is correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It is a welcome sign since it indicates descent fetal head into pelvis. Explanation: Some important point regarding contractile system of myometrium:- Lightening: Few (2-3) weeks prior to the onset of labor especially in primigravidae, the presenting part descent into the true pelvis, reduces fundal pressure on the diaphragm and relieve the mechanical cardiorespiratory embarrassment. There may be frequency of micturition or constipation due to pressure by the engaged presenting part. It is a welcome sign which rules out cephalopelvic disproportion and other conditions preventing the head from entering the pelvic inlet. Cervical changes: Few days prior to the onset of labor, cervix becomes ripe which is- soft, 80

Unification operation done for bicornuate/septate uterus- Abdominal metroplasty could be done either by excising the septum (Strassman, Jones, and Jones) or by incising the septum (Tompkins). Hysteroscopic resection is considered best.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the clinical features of hyperprolactinemia? 
1. Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism 
2. Hypogonadotropic hypergonadism 
3. Oligomenorrhea 
4. Heavy menstruation 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.

Which of the following are effective in the management of premenstrual syndrome? 
1. Niacin (vitamin B3) 
2. Combined oral contraceptive pills 
3. Diuretics 
4. Hysterectomy with oophorectomy
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 2, 3 and 4 
Explanation: Some important point about premenstrual
syndrome (PMS), or premenstrual tension (PMT) . ? Psychoneuroendocrine disorder of unknown
etiology, often noticed just prior to menstruation. Occurs 7-10 days prior to menstruation and
resolves spontaneously after menses. ? It should fulfill the following criteria (ACOG): (a) Not related to
any organic lesion, (b) Regularly occurs during the luteal phase of each ovulatory menstrual cycle, (c)
Symptoms must be severe enough to disturb the lifestyle of the woman or she requires medical help
(d) Symptom-free period during rest of the cycle. ? Common in middle-aged women. Exact cause not
known. Comprises physical, psychological and behavioral changes not associated with organic lesion.
Prevalent in 5% women. . Low level of ?-endorphins (neurotransmitters) in the brain and low level of
serotonin are responsible for psychiatric disorders. ? Diagnosis mainly by clinical Symptoms are
related to water retention (abdominal bloating/ cramp, breast tenderness, swelling of the extremities,
weight gain). neuropsychiatric symptoms (low performance, irritability, depression, mood swings,
forgetfulness, restlessness, increased appetite, tearfulness, anxiety, tension, confusion, headache,
anger, feel like crying), behavioral symptoms (fatigue, dyspareunia, tiredness, insomnia), autonomic
changes (dizziness, faintness, nausea, vomiting, hot flushes) ? Treatment- For psychological
symptoms (psychotherapy), counseling and reassurance, yoga, stress management, diet
manipulation, avoidance of salt, caffeine and alcohol specially in the second half of the cycle for the
milder cases. Vitamins B, Be and E. selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor like sertraline, citalopram,
anxiolytics (alprazolam), TCA, GABA agonists are effective, For breast pain - Danazol, bromocryptine,
GnRh analog. For pelvic pain and bloatedness- Yasmin, primrose prostaglandin inhibitors (Mefenamic
acid), OCP, progestogens, Mirena IUCD, spironolactones and other diuretics. Hysterectomy with
removal of ovaries is a last resort

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Polycystic ovarian syndrome Explanation: PALM-COEIN (FIGO-2011) classification used to classify the abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) on the basis of etiology. Normal menstrual bleeding have cervical interval 28 days (21-35), menstrual flow 4-5 days, normal menstrual blood loss 35ml (20-80ml). PALM-COEIN classification:

The reference point 'zero' in POPQ (Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification) classification is taken as:

Which of the following are the various treatment options for Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome
(TTTS)? 
1. Septostomy 
2. Laser photocoagulation 
3. Selective fetal reduction 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Some important point regarding twin-twin
transfusion syndrome (TTTS) ? In monozygotic twins only; one twin bleed into the other through some
kind of placental vascular anastomosis. ? Symptoms are due to unidirectional deep AV anastomoses.
Receptor twin becomes larger with hydramnios, polycythemic, hypertensive and hypervolemic, while
donor twin becomes smaller with oligohydramnios, anemic, hypotensive and hypovolemic. Difference
of Hb concentration between the two twin exceeds 5 g% and weight > 25%. ? Diagnosis - Ultrasound
with Doppler blood flow study in the placental vascular bed. ? T/T-Repeated amniocentesis to control
polyhydramnios in recipient twin, Septostomy (making a hole in the dividing amniotic membrane),
Laser photocoagulation, Selective fetal reduction of one twin when survival of both is at risk. Smaller
twin -better outcome. The plethoric twin has risk of CCF and hydrops. Congenital abnormalities
(neural tube defects, holoprosencephaly) are 2-3 times. Perinatal mortality is 70%. Dead fetus
syndrome-Death of one twin (2-7%) is associated with poor outcome of other (25%) especially in
monochorionic placenta. The surviving twin has risk of cerebral palsy, microcephaly, renal cortical
necrosis and DIC due to thromboplastin liberated from the dead twin that crosses via placenta to the
living twin.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs should be avoided in labouring women with bronchial asthma? 
1. Opioid analgesics 
2. Prostaglandin F2a 
3. Prostaglandin El 
4. Ergometrine 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 1, 2 and 4 Explanation: Management of acute asthma in pregnancy
Avoidance of asthma triggers (allergens, irritant), oxygen inhalation with mask to maintain O2
saturation > 95%. High dose albuterol by nebulization every 20 minutes and inhaled ipratropium
bromide and systemic corticosteroid. IV hydrocortisone 200 mg stat and to be repeated after 4 hours
and given along with ?2-agonists. FEV1 or peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) < 50> 42
mm Hg need intubation and mechanical ventilation. Labor ? PEFR or FEVI should be determined,
medications to be continued. FEV1 ? 70%, ? Opiate analgesics are bronchoconstrictor and respiratory
depressant so avoided. Labetalol precipitates asthma. ? Hydrocortisone during labor and 24 hours
postpartum is to be given. Inhaled steroid (fluticasone, udesonide) should be given ? Syntocinon
given, ergometrine and PGF2a causes bronchoconstriction so avoided. PGE1 and PGE2 compounds
are used. ? Epidural anesthesia is preferable. Halothane is better in general anesthesia if has to be
given, it produces uterine atony. ? Ketamine is used for induction it prevents bronchospasm.
Postnatal physiotherapy is maintained and drugs are continued. ? Breastfeeding should be
encouraged. Prednisolone, corticosteroids, LABA, LTRA does not contraindicate breast feeding.

questions.text:
A patient delivered a live healthy baby 4 hours back. Now she has developed persistent severe
pain in the perineal region and rectal tenesmus. Local examination reveals a tense and tender purple
swelling at the vulva. What is her probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Pelvic hematoma Explanation: Pelvic hematoma ? Collection of blood
anywhere in the area between the pelvic peritoneum and the perineal skin is called pelvic hematoma.
Commonest type is the vulval hematoma. ? Etiology: Improper hemostasis during repair of vaginal or
perineal tears or episiotomy wound, failure to take precaution during suturing the apex, failure to
obliterate the dead space, rupture of paravaginal venous plexus ? C/f-Persistent, severe pain on the
perineal region. rectal tenesmus or bearing down efforts, retention of urine, shock, tense, tender
swelling at the vulva which becomes dusky and purple ? T/t-small hematoma (<5 cm) treated
conservatively. Larger hematomas should be explored under general anesthesia. Simultaneous clots
are removed and bleeding secured, antibiotic, Foley catheterisation Rupture of uterus:- features
During Pregnancy: ? Scar rupture: dull abdominal pain over the scar area with slight vaginal bleeding,
tenderness on uterine palpation; FHS irregular or absent. Sense of something giving way
accompanied by acute abdominal pain and collapse. ? Spontaneous rupture: high parous women.
Onset is usually acute but sometimes insidious. Acute types- acute pain abdomen with fainting
attacks, shock, acute tenderness on abdominal examination, palpation of superficial fetal parts, if the
rupture is complete and absence of fetal heart rate change of uterine contour. In insidious onsetdiagnosis
is often confused with concealed accidental hemorrhage or rectus sheath hematoma. ?
Lower segment scar rupture during labour- insidious onset. Confirmation is by laparotomy. ? Rupture
following manipulative or instrumental delivery: Sudden deterioration, vaginal bleeding following
manipulative or instrumental delivery. Exploration of uterus to feel the rent confirms the diagnosis.
Shortening of the cord immediately following a difficult vaginal delivery is pathognomonic. Cervical
tear ? Commonest cause of traumatic postpartum hemorrhage. Left lateral tear is commonest. ?
Attempted forceps delivery or breech extraction in incompletely dilated cervix, rigid cervix,
previously operated, precipitate labor or extremely vascular cervix as in placenta ? Diagnosis -
excessive vaginal bleeding immediately following delivery in hard and contracted uterus. Exploration
confirms the diagnosis but also helps to know the extent of the tear. ? Complication - Early-severe
PPH, broad ligament hematoma. pelvic cellulitis, thrombophlebitis. Late - ectropion, cervical
incompetence with midtrimester abortion. ? T/t - Deep cervical tear with bleeding repaired soon after
delivery of the placenta under general anesthesia, Reference: Dutta obs 8/493, 9 399-401

questions.text:

Which of the following statements have obstetric significance at the level of plane of least pelvic
dimensions? 
1. It is a landmark used for pudendal nerve block analgesia. 
2. Deep transverse arrest usually occurs at this plane. 
3. It is at this plane that the internal rotation of the fetal head occurs during labour. 
4. It marks the beginning of the backward curve of the pelvic axis. 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Plane of least pelvic dimensions- ? Plane
extends from the lower border of the symphysis pubis to the tip of ischial spines and posteriorly to
meet the tip of the fifth sacral vertebra, oval shape. Diameters are: Plane of greatest pelvic
dimensions- ? Plane extends from the midpoint of posterior surface of symphysis pubis to the junction
of second and third sacral vertebrae. It is the most roomy plane of the pelvis and is almost round in
shape Obstetric Significance of Plane of Least Pelvic dimension:- ? It is the narrowest plane in the
pelvis; this plane corresponds roughly to the origin of levator ani muscles. At this plane internal
rotation of the fetal head occurs. It marks the beginning of the forward curve of the pelvic axis. It is a
landmark used for pudendal nerve block analgesia. This level of ischial spines indicate Station 'O. It is
irregularly oval and notched on each side by ischial spine.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: For screening of diabetes only "high-risk" groups should consider. These are: (i) age group ≥ 40, (ii) those with a family history of diabetes, (iii) obese, (iv) women who have had a baby weighing more than 4.5 kg (or 3 .5 kg in constitutionally small populations), (v) women having excess weight gain during pregnancy, and (vi) patients with premature atherosclerosis. questions.text: What is the shelf life of Dukoral (wc-rBS) oral vaccine used for cholera prevention, when stored at a temperature of 2°C to 8°C?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 3 years Explanation: Three types of oral cholera vaccines are available
Dukoral (WC-rBS)- ? Monovalent vaccine whole cells of V. cholerae 01 (classical and El Tor, Inaba and
Ogawa) plus recombinant cholera toxin B subunit. Vaccine has a shelf life of 3 years at 2-8°C and
remains stable for 1 month at 37°C ? For primary immunization 2 oral doses given 27 days apart (<6> 6weeks for primary immunisation than it should restarted. One booster dose after 2 years for adult
and ? 6 years old children. If the interval between the primary and booster immunization is >2 years,
primary immunization must be repeated. Not given for children aged <2 years Sanchol and
mORCVAX ? The closely related bivalent oral cholera vaccines are based on serogroups O1 and O139.
Not contain the bacterial toxin B subunit so not require buffer. Administered orally in 2 liquid doses
14 days apart for aged 1 year. Booster dose is recommended after 2 years. Euvichol has same
characteristics as Sanchol

questions.text: Which one of the following international agencies focuses on the 'Country Health Programming' approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) The United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) Explanation: In 1953, "U.N.
Children's Fund" was named by UNICEF. UNICEF's south central regional office is at Kathmandu Nepal
and headquarters of the UNICEF is at New York. Country health programming approach by UNICEF is
currently interested so as to meet the needs of children as an integral part of the country's
development effort. Content of services (a) Child health: Provide aid for the production of vaccines
and sera, assisted environmental sanitation programmes emphasizing safe and sufficient water for
drinking and household use in rural areas, focusing attention on providing primary health care to
mothers and children. (b) Child nutrition: High priority to improving child nutrition through aiding
"applied nutrition" programmes and supplying large doses of vitamin A, salt with iodine, iron and
folate supplements with FAQ, and WHO. (c) Family and child welfare: To improve the care of children,
both within and outside their homes (d) Education-formal and non-forma: In collaboration with
UNESCO, in the expansion and improvement of teaching science in India. UNICEF is promoting a GOBI
campaign to encourage 4 strategies for a child health revolution": ? G for growth charts to better
monitor child development ? O for oral rehydration to treat all mild and moderate dehydration ? B for
breast feeding; and ? I for immunization against measles, diphtheria, polio, pertussis, tetanus and
tuberculosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about 'End TB Strategy'? 
1. The strategy goes beyond patient care to promote TB prevention. 
2. The targets are to be achieved by 2035. 
3. The milestone for 2025 is to reduce the TB deaths by 35% compared to 2015. 
4. The strategy identifies four barriers to achieve progress in fight against TB. 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1, 2 and 4 Explanation: Some important point regarding "End TB strategy":- question may be asked in future- Measured by the number of people who die each year due to tuberculosis, it is the deadliest infectious disease. The WHO "End TB strategy". adopted by the World Health Assembly in May 2014. The DOTS strategy (1994) helped revitalize national tuberculosis programmes and equivalent entities by putting in place the essential basics to address the TB epidemic. The "Stop TB strategy" (2006) broadened the response by addressing the emerging challenges of HIV associated TB and MDR-TB etc. It improves access to quality TB care by engaging all public and private care providers, civil society organizations and communities. The End TB Strategy (2015) encompasses a package of interventions that can be fully adopted at country level. The strategy envisions universal access to high-quality TB care and goes beyond it to promote TB prevention. The End TB Strategy identifies four barriers in the fight against TB. These are (a) weak health system. (b) underlying determinants of TB such as poverty, undernutrition, migration and ageing population and risk factors such as diabetes, silicosis and smoking etc, (3) lack of effective tools, and (4) continuous unmet- funding needs. Some other points regarding End TB strategy

Select the correct answer using the code given below.
Throughout history, humans have been adapting environment to the genes more than adapting genes to the environment. Adapting environment to the genes is called
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Euthenics Explanation: Euthenics: - Mere improvement of the genotype
is of no use unless the improved genotype is given access to a suitable environment, an environment
which will enable the genes to express themselves readily. Man has been adapting environment to
his genes more than adapting his genes to the environment. Exposure to environmental stimulation
improved their IQ in mild retarded children. The solution of improving the human race does not lie in
contrasting heredity and environment, but rather in the mutual interaction of heredity and
environmental factors. This environmental manipulation is called euthenics. Eugenics: - Science
which aims to improve the genetic endowment of human population (Galton). Negative eugenics:
Hitler sought to improve the German race by killing the weak and defective which is not acceptable in
civil society; this was negative eugenics. If people who are suffering from serious hereditary diseases
may sterilized or debarred from producing children to reduce disease. The aim of negative eugenics
is to reduce the frequency of hereditary disease. In spite of eugenic sterilization, new cases of
hereditary diseases will continue to arise in the population because of fresh mutations, and hidden
carriers (heterozygotes) of recessive defects Positive eugenics: More ambitious programme than
47
negative eugenics. It seeks to improve the genetic composition of the population by encouraging the
carriers of desirable genotypes to assume the burden of parenthood. At present, it has very little
application. Acculturation: Acculturation means "culture contact" When there is contact between two
people with different types of culture, there is diffusion of culture both ways. These are: Trade and
commerce, industrialization, propagation of religion, education (introduction of scientific medicine);
and conquest. It has both good and bad aspects The British brought their culture in India through
conquest.

questions.text:
In a town, a study was carried out to determine the role of cigarette smoking in causation of lung cancer. It was found that a total of 7000 people in the town were smokers. Of them, 70 developed lung cancer. In the same town, 3000 people were non-smokers. Of them, 3 developed lung cancer. Given these numbers, what would be the attributable risk to cigarette. smoking for lung
cancer?

A town in the hills had a mid-year population of 250000 in the year 2021. During the same year, the death registry of the town recorded 1500 deaths due to tuberculosis in 365 calendar days. Given these facts, what is the specific death rate for tuberculosis in the town?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 6 Explanation: Specific death rates:- They permit comparisons between different causes within the same population. Specific death rates are obtained mainly in countries in which a satisfactory civil registration system operates and in which a high proportion of deaths is certified medically.

questions.text:
Which of the following 'rare vaccine reactions' are known to occur with BCG vaccine? 
1. Suppurative lymphadenitis 
2. Guillain-Barre syndrome 
3. Osteitis 
4. Disseminated infection 
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
Which one of the following vaccines is known to interfere with the Yellow Fever vaccine if administered within 3 weeks of each other?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Cholera vaccine Explanation: For jungle yellow fever, vaccination of
humans with 17D vaccine is the only control measure. Urban yellow fever.- Rapid immunization of the
population at risk is the most effective control strategy. For international use, the approved vaccine is
the live attenuated, heat sensitive, 17D vaccine. Stored between +5 and - 30 deg.C, preferably below
zero deg. C, reconstituted vaccine should be kept on ice, away from sunlight, and discarded if not
used within half an hour. 0.5 ml single dose SC administration at deltoid irrespective of age.
Immunity appear on the 7th day and lasts for life. People who should not be vaccinated include;children aged under 9 months for routine immunization (or under 6 months during an epidemic),
pregnant women, people with severe allergies to egg protein; and people with severe
immunodeficiency or in thymus disorder. Cholera and yellow fever vaccines together or within 3
weeks interfere with each other, so whenever possible, they should be given 3 weeks or more apart.

questions.text:
Regarding the Vandemataram Scheme, consider the following statements: 
1. It is a voluntary scheme wherein any obstetrician, maternity home, nursing home, MBBS doctor can provide safe
mother Yoo hood services. 
2. The enrolled doctors must provide iron and folic acid tablets out of their
pocket free to the beneficiaries. 
3. The TT injections are provided by the District Medical Officers to the enrolled doctors for free administration to the ben eficiaries. 
4. To join the Vandemataram Scheme, the facility must have resources for caesarean section. Which of the statements given above are correct?

Consider the following measures which can help make 'unlined katcha wells' sanitary: 
1. Deepening the bottom 
2. Filling the well with clay up to the water level and with coarse sand above that level 
3. Installing a hand pump with screen 
4. Constructing a platform and drainage once the material used for filling is completely consolidated 
Which of these measures hold good in making unlined katcha wells sanitary?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 1, 3 and 4 only 
Explanation: The unlined katcha wells may be made
sanitary by deepening the bottom, installing a hand-pump with screen, and filling the well with coarse
sand up to the water level, and with clay above that level. When the material used for filling is
completely consolidated a platform and drainage may be constructed. Masonry well improvement
consists of making the upper 10 feet or more of the lining water-tight, raising the lining one foot
above the ground, and providing a reinforced concrete slab cover at the top. Sanitary well: one which
is properly located, well constructed and protected against contamination with a view to yield a
supply of safe water. Point to be taken into consideration during making well:- Location: well should
be located not less than 15 m (50 feet) from likely sources of contamination. Should located at a
higher elevation with respect to a possible source of contamination. Distance should be less than 100
m (100 yards) Lining should be built of bricks or stones set in cement up to a depth of at least 6 m
(20 feet) so that water enters from the bottom. Lining should be carried 60-90 cm (2-3 feet) above
the ground level and a parapet wall up to a height of at least 70-75 cm (28 inches) above the ground.
Cement- concrete platform round the well extending at least 1 m (3 feet) in all directions and pucca
drain. Top of the well should be closed by a cement concrete cover and equipped with a hand-pump
for lifting the water in a sanitary manner. Tube well: Yield water which is bacteriologically safe. A
water-tight concrete platform with a drain all round should be provided. Area within 15 m of the tube
well should be kept free from pollution with liquid and solid wastes. The life of the tube well varies
from place to place depending upon the type of strainer, quality of underground water and the nature
of soil. Average well may last for a period of 5 to 10 years; even upto 30 years. Chandigarh, the
capital of Punjab, derives its entire water supply from tube wells.

choices.text:
Membrane filtration technique is much quicker and A. results can be obtained within 20 hours, while multiple tube
method is much longer.
Membrane filtration technique is far cheaper than multiple tube method.
Membrane filtration technique is universally available, and hence, easily doable.

Membrane filtration technique can be employed by all and sundry, whereas multiple tube method can only be
carried out by trained hands.

questions.text: In which way is 'membrane filtration technique' better than 'multiple tube method' for determining the presence of coliform organisms in water?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Membrane filtration technique is much quicker and results can be
obtained within 20 hours, while multiple tube method is much longer. Explanation: Presumptive
coliform test (i) Multiple tube method: Test is based on estimating the most probable number of
coliform organisms in 100 ml of water. Inoculation of measured quantities of the sample water done
for 48 hours into tubes of McConkey's Lactose Bile Salt Broth with bromcresol purple as an indicator
and "presumptive coliform count", obtained. Confirmatory tests required in chlorinated water.
Confirmation is done by subculturing each positive tube in 2 tubes of brilliant green bile broth, one of
which is incubated at 37 deg C for up to 48 hours and the other incubated at 44°C and inspected
after 6 and 24 hours to decide E. coli is present or not. E. coli is only coliform organism which is
capable of producing gas from lactose at 44 deg C. if needed further confirmation done by testing for
indol production at 44 °C. (ii) Membrane filtration technique: In some countries membrane filter
technique is used as a standard procedure to test for the presence of coliform organisms through a
membrane made of cellulose ester. Bacteria present in water are retained on the surface of the
membrane and by inoculating it on suitable media at appropriate temperature, it is possible to count
the colonies and obtain results within 20 hours as compared to 72-96 hours required for the usual
multiple tube technique.

questions.text: Of the following amino acids required by the human body, which one falls under the category of essential' amino acid?

Consider the following statements with reference to the National Framework for Malaria
Elimination in India, 2016- 2030: 
1. The goal is to eliminate indigenous cases throughout the country by 2030. 
2. By 2022, transmission of malaria is to be interrupted and indigenous cases brought to zero in all 26 States/UTs that were under Categories 1 and 2 in 2014. 
3. By 2026, incidence of malaria is to be reduced to less than 1 case per 1000 population in all States and UTs, and their districts. 
4. By 2030, indigenous transmission of malaria is to be interrupted in all States and UTs of India. Which of the statements given above hold true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1 and 2 only Explanation: National Framework for Malaria Elimination in
India (2016-2030) The National Framework for malaria elimination in India 2016-2030 was launched
in February 2016. Goals ? Eliminate malaria (zero indigenous cases) throughout the entire country by
2030; and ? Maintain malaria-free status in areas where malaria transmission has been interrupted
and prevent reintroduction of malaria. Objectives ? By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and
zero indigenous cases to be attained in all 26 States/UTs that were under Categories 1 and 2 in 2014
? By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to less than 1 case per 1000 population in all States
and UTs, and their districts ? By 2027, indigenous transmission of malaria to be interrupted in all
States and UTs of India; and ? By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the entire country, and
re-establishment of transmission prevented.

questions.text:
With reference to determinants of 'neonatal mortality, consider the following statements: 
1. Neonatal mortality is directly related to the birth weight of the newborn. 
2. Neonatal mortality is directly related to the gestational age at which the birth takes place. 
3. Neonatal mortality is closely related to the educational status of the mother. 
4. Neonatal mortality is low if the mother's age is between 15-16 years. 
Which of the statements given above are correct?

As per the definition of the World Health Organization, 'late maternal death' is defined as the death of a woman from direct or indirect obstetric causes, after more than X days but less than one year after termination of pregnancy. Which one among the following is the correct value of X?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 42 Explanation: Late maternal death is defined as "the death of a women from direct or indirect causes, more than 42 days but less than one year after termination of pregnancy (ICD-10) Pregnancy-related death: Death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the cause of death Maternal death: defined as "the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes- Maternal mortality ratio measures women dying from "puerperal causes" and is defined as:-

Select the correct answer using the code given below.

The following table shows the 'Total Fertility Rate (TFR)' by the Wealth Index, as per the National Family Health Survey, (NFHS-4) findings

Which among the following is/are correct about the information?

1. The divisions of Wealth Index in the NFHS-4 can be called 'quartiles.

2. The information given in the table can be presented as a pie chart.

3. The Wealth Index was calculated in NFHS-4 by asking about the per capita income.

4. Each of the higher divisions of the Wealth Index had lower TFR than the previous (or lower) division. Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 4 only Explanation: National Family Health Survey (NFHS) and wealth
index ? Wealth was divided into quintiles and not quartiles. Wealth was divided into five parts/ groups
with equal number of individual in each. As seen in the table also and present in the report. Five parts
is quintiles (Wealth index quintiles - poorest, second, middle, fourth, richest). Four is quartiles. ? It
cannot be presented in pie chart because TFR is not a proportion which would add up to 100%. ?
Wealth index is index of the economic status of households and is based on consumption of
consumer goods. It is an indicator of the level of wealth that is consistent with expenditure and
income measures. Wealth index Households are given scores based on the number and kinds of
consumer goods they own, ranging from a television to a bicycle or car, and housing characteristics
such as source of drinking water, toilet facilities, and flooring materials etc. These scores are derived
using principal component analysis. Infant mortality rates are high in lowest wealth index households and lowest among the highest wealth index households ? As wealth quintile rises TFR decreases. So
option "d" is only correct
